text: if I told you that today is my 27th
birthday and was spending it in the
Maldives you'd probably think that I'm
spending it at a luxury resort with a
private beach and maybe glass-bottom
bungalows right nope you see the
Maldives doesn't have to be expensive
and there is a thriving culture that I'm
eager to learn about this morning we
took a speedboat to one of the 200
locally inhabited islands called
mabushii thank the body where we checked
into this cheap hotel for $30 a night
not 3,000 not 330 today I'm going to
introduce you to the unseen side of
money via culture and show you how easy
it is to travel here on a budget I got
in touch with some locals
Keshawn a and so t hey who are kind
enough to show me local life on the
island yes it's to start a rainy season
and it's been windy and pouring since we
arrived but that's part of the
experience this is just your average
island life something interesting I
learned is that before 2012 the
Maldivian government prohibited tourists
to stay overnight on local islands like
Malucci so it was almost impossible to
travel to this country on a budget but
now the government allows locals to have
small businesses like cafes and guest
houses and it's booming
I was told I cannot come to the Maldives
until I tried their coconuts so I headed
to this local shop and got one for two
bucks rest assured it's pretty good the
Maldives is a predominantly Muslim
country and there are four mosques on
this island I'm here during Ramadan the
holiest month in the Muslim religion
which means they don't eat from sunrise
to sunset for a month we headed to the
biggest mosque to see if dark or
breaking the fast it was really a
special experience to witness this and
they all welcomed me with free food and
open arms it's an Islamic tradition to
break the fast with dates and they are
really tasty it's officially 613 the
sound of prayers illuminate the island
and it's time to eat and drink
afterwards I was welcomed into a local
house to eat a home-cooked iftar dinner
there's a lot of food here we're gonna
break the fast for Ramadan they were
cooking kebab ooh bowl Kiba which is
like fish coconut and rice balls spicy
pasta chicken sandwiches and vegetables
it was spicy so much good local food and
it all costs $5 at the local market this
is what a typical plate looks like to
break the fast
whose fish cakes man I'm bringing em
back to America today was an amazing day
and I spent just $40 on everything
including a hotel and dinner the moral
of the story is that you don't have to
be surrounded by tourists or spend
thousands of dollars on a glass-bottom
bungalow to have a good time in the
MALDI because views like this and this
will be the same regardless of which bed
you sleep in
I'm drew Vince key and if you like my
travel videos please click Subscribe and
join me as I plan to visit every country
in the world
